properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected Wednesday and Wednesday night. Snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday morning and persist through Wednesday night. Furthermore, strong northwest winds gusting to 50 km/h is expected to result in blowing snow. Total local snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are possible by Thursday morning when the squalls are forecast to shift out of the region and gradually weaken. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T19:26:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-18T03:27:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2687941097.2019
Area: Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County, London - Parkhill - Eastern Middlesex County, Strathroy - Komoka - Western Middlesex County, Woodstock - Tillsonburg - Oxford County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Brief periods of heavy snow are possible early this morning, including during the morning commute, as a cold front sweeps through the area. This afternoon and evening there is the risk of snow squalls extending into the area from Georgian Bay. Total snowfall amounts of 5 cm are possible by this evening over a few locales. Travel could be hazardous at times due to reduced visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T22:21:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-18T06:22:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1098747571.2019
Area: Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Vaughan - Richmond Hill - Markham
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for this evening into the overnight hours. Brief periods of heavy snow and reduced visibility are expected this evening and overnight as lake effect snow sweeps through the region. Snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are possible before tapering to scattered flurries before morning. Snow at times heavy could make travel hazardous due to reduced visibilities. Be prepared for quickly changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T14:59:04-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility due to blowing snow have developed at Coral Harbour. Blizzard conditions are expected to last through the overnight hours. The blizzard will ease on Wednesday morning. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values of minus 40 are expected early this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm continues. Heavy snow continues to fall across northern Alberta. The snow will taper off from west to east overnight, after it brings a total of 10 to 15 centimetres to the region. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. A building surface ridge of high pressure will give strong winds near the Richardson Mountains today. Strong easterly winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 will cause blizzard conditions with near zero visibility. Winds will ease somewhat this evening and become intermittent. Local blowing snow is still possible near the Richardson Mountains tonight through Wednesday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T16:24:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-18T02:22:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2004795423.2019
Area: Dempster

properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for overnight and Wednesday morning. Snow squalls will be possible overnight into Wednesday morning as strong winds help snow bands penetrate far inland from Georgian Bay. Travel may be hazardous at times due to heavy snow and blowing snow reducing visibilities and rapidly changing conditions. Local snowfall amounts of near 10 cm will be possible by late Wednesday morning when the squalls move out of the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 50 and minus 55. Wind chill values near minus 50 are occurring tonight. These extreme cold conditions are expected to continue Wednesday and Thursday. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h, combined with 2 to 4 cm of fresh snow, will produce blizzard conditions this afternoon in Resolute. The whiteout conditions are forecast to persist through the evening and end overnight as winds gradually diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls today into this evening. Snow squalls are forecast to persist into this evening. Furthermore, strong northwest winds gusting to 60 km/h will produce widespread blowing snow today. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible for southern sections of the Bruce Peninsula by this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls today into tonight. Snow squalls are forecast to persist into the overnight hours, with the most intense snow squalls expected this morning and afternoon. Furthermore, strong northwest winds gusting to 60 km/h will result in widespread blowing snow. Additional local snowfall amounts of 20 to 35 cm are possible by Thursday morning. The snow squalls are forecast to gradually weaken overnight and Thursday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong westerly winds associated with a low pressure system crossing northern Alberta will bring gusts up to 100 km/h this evening to areas along the southern foothills, such as Pincher Creek and Waterton Lakes National Park. These strong winds will gradually weaken overnight. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A strong Pacific frontal system over northern Vancouver Island will remain nearly stationary tonight then shift southward on Wednesday. This storm is forecast to bring widespread heavy rainfall to the west coast of Vancouver Island. For Tofino and communities further north such as Zeballos and Tahsis, heavy rain is expected to continue tonight. As the front begins to move southward early Wednesday, heavy rain will start to impact communities south of Tofino. Total rainfall amounts in the range of 100 to 150 mm can be expected for this event. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T15:55:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T23:56:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1330004674.2019
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada
